CatDescriptText: Mr. John Smart, laborer, Euclid Avenue, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 5, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "If you were advising a Negro high school student, who plans to enter college and is seeking help on choosing a vocation, what field would you suggest that he or she seek as a vocation?" Answer reads: "Nothing is more important to us, as people, than our health.  Health is first.  Under that condition, which we recognize, without argument, there is nothing more important for a young student to attempt than a study of medicine.  People are more sickly than we realize, so we need men and women who know what to do for our ills.  Yes, I place medicine out front, as a most important vocation, for our students."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of John Smart wearing moustache and two toned striped short sleeve polo shirt, standing in front of light colored wall
